OUR TEMPERANCE WORK.

Conducted by the W.C.T.U. of Brandon.
Work I: Work 2:

Come, labor on! What dawns dark-side life in the harmonious plan of the universe? And how does it serve the master art?
Come, labor on! The great calling angels cannot escape, nor can we who love our Lord, be exempted from the duties which God has laid upon us.
Come, labor on! The energy is watching, night and day, while slumbering slants their daily handiwork.
Come, labor on! How pleasantly do the morn and the cool evening come and go, how dear their joy, how deep their sorrow is.
Come, labor on!

For every man and woman, borders to visit every patron at the Post Office Bookstore.

Women's Temperance Union.

At the recent meeting of this Union, Mrs. Harvey spoke so eloquently in favor of the temperance question, that she was heard by all present, and it was evident that there might be a possibility of success in the work. The cause of temperance is being steadily advanced, both spiritually and spiritually by the Union. It is felt that the influence of temperance in the home is not only desirable, but essential for the welfare of the community at large. It is felt that the work of temperance is a noble one, and that the women of Canada should take an active part in promoting it.

We will send the following three Books for examination: "The Canadian Temperance," a complete medical advice book for women; "How to Make and Keep Your Own Tea," price $1; "Pen and Canvas," a guide for keeping house, to make over the use of candles and gas, and save money; and "The Ladies' Guide to Fancy Work," a practical guide to all ladies interested in the art. We are also sending "Art Matters," containing a large amount of useful information for the housewife. Encouragingly, we have just received from Mr. Henry, of London, Ontario, a copy of the journal "The Canadian Temperance," which contains many interesting articles and stories. We will be pleased to send any of these books, and we would encourage all women to study them. For each of the above, send $1.00 to LADIES' GOLD NECKLACE COMPANY, THE CANADIAN CO., N.Y., N.Y.

PRESBYTERIANS.

Synod of Manitoba and the N.W. Territories.

Brandon, Thursday, May 21.

The Synod was convened at 10 a.m. The Rev. Mr. Macdonald, Principal of Brandon College, presided. The Revs. K. M. Murray and Mr. Ross Evans delivered addresses. The object of the exercise was the prosperity of the Presbyterian Church in Manitoba. The Rev. Mr. Macdonald, in his address, stated that he had set sail from England with the intention of visiting the United States, but was obliged to change his plans due to unforeseen circumstances. He expressed his gratitude to the congregation for their hospitality and support.

Mr. Macdonald then addressed the congregation, emphasizing the importance of the Presbyterian Church in maintaining its principles and traditions. He encouraged the congregation to continue their support of the church and its mission. The Rev. Mr. Murray then delivered an address on the importance of education in the Presbyterian Church. He emphasized the need for education in order to maintain the integrity and purity of the faith.

Mr. Evans then delivered an address on the importance of the Presbyterian Church in promoting social justice and equality. He encouraged the congregation to continue their support of the church and its mission. The Rev. Mr. Macdonald then delivered a final address, thanking the congregation for their support and expressing his hope for the continued prosperity of the Presbyterian Church in Manitoba.

The Synod adjourned at 12 noon, with prayers offered by the Rev. Mr. Macdonald.
I take pleasure in informing the Citizens of Brandon and residents of the vicinity, that I have opened a new Book and Stationery store in the Post Office Building Masonic Block, where I should be pleased to meet all in need of any goods in my line.

I will always keep on hand a full line of plain and fancy Stationery, miscellaneous and Church books, and light reading.

ALL SCHOOL REQUISITES, LEGAL BLANKS AND LEGAL STATIONERY, Of every description; fancy goods in variety:

TOYS for the children, etc., etc.; in fact everything kept in a well appointed business.

I have formed such business connections as will enable me to get anything in any line not in stock on the shortest notice. Special rates will be given to School Trustees and Teachers, Municipalities and other corporations that require large quantities of anything in my line. Any paper, book, or magazine published, will be secured and sent to any address on the shortest possible notice.

C. CLIFFE.

TO OUR SUBSCRIBERS.

We have now completed our second number of the "Brandon Weekly Mail," which will shortly appear in a third number. We wish to inform our subscribers that we will issue our ninth number soon after this current paper goes to press.

CALLED BACK

By Henri Gaudet.

Poveshell has been called back from his last words. He promised that he would return to his former position, but he did not do so. The following is what he said:

"I have heard your words, but I cannot return to my former position. I am not willing to do so."

Burlington

SHOAL LAKE

The undersigned now offers for sale some good lots in the TOWN OF BURLINGTON situated at the Narrows of Shoal Lake.

The location is one of the finest in the Northwest, and having the prospects of the early construction of the M. & N.W. Railroad through the place.

It is destined to be NOT ONLY a good place of business, but

A PLEASURE RESORT!

being situated at a Beautiful Clear Water Lake, nearly two miles away by five long miles of water, abundant with plenty of fine fish and good shooting. It has nice scenery around the lake. Its banks being high & gravelly covered with timber. Also a fine view of the Riding Mountains, a distance of 12 miles off. Although not centered in a large extent of agricultural lands which is necessary for the class of farmers it is bound to become a large town.

For further information or a view of plans may be seen at the office of

MORPHY & STEWART,
Burlington, Man.
